title: Wow... Its laughable how 'loyal' people are to Azir.
body:
Azir had enjoyed around 3% pick rate since his arrival into League of Legends, then Easyhoon played him and everyone realised he was strong in the tank meta and within a fortnight Azir's pick rate skyrocketed to around 15% and stayed there for the whole season and his ban-rate was triple that, and now Azir gets a few nerfs and suddenly over another fortnight he is back to around 4% again.

So much for loyalty aye.

It just shows that most people only play champions for power and don't give a shit about the actual champ design.

replies.body:
The thing is, he is still stupidly strong if you are skilled with him.

It's not like they nerfed Vayne out of existence (wish they would) take away Silver Bolts the only thing overpowered on her and she'll never get played again.

I know he is still powerful, he is one of my mains, i just find it funny how Riot still acts like they believe champion design is the main factor that attracts players, when its clear to everyone that power is the only thing 80% of the population cares about.

As for Vayne, (I wish she would disappear from the game as well), I can live with the silver bolts, and even (god forbid) her invisibility, the thing that i cant stand is her passive. 
_"Yes she's invisible and does % health true damage, and thats OP as fuck, But it cant hurt you if you run away from it?... oh wait, you cant run away from it.... So if we cant run away from it, then we have to kill her first?... oh wait she has the highest DPS in the game is invisible and is the only ADC with a stun... RIP me."_

The chase mechanic is fine, most ADCs have something similar like Draven's Stand Aside.

It's just Silver Bolts that is the problem. Whoever thought increasing it to 12% needs to be hung.
It could be easily balanced by being changed to physical or magic, or current health.

Riot don't deliberately make a champion overpowered or underpowered, they want everything to be on equal play field, it's more healthy for your game that way, and the more champs that are popular the more skins you'll sell overall.
They are getting the hang of it, and have a much better grasp of the situation than other companies. (looking at you Valve)
Selling skins is well your best way of making money for LoL, if the champion pool is stagnant then you aren't going to make anything, however if you make sure your game is well balanced that a large portion of your selection is being used you'll sell more skins.

Ryze is a great current example with his newest rework.
He's quite well balanced between skill and raw power. (though if you want to get the most out of him you're going to set your keyboard on fire due to the high speed friction)
New champs have also been quite underwhelming on release for sometime, I can't think of the last champ to come out that was considering OP on release.
Might have been Vel'Koz or Yasuo, though I remember their launches being pretty meh.
People thought Illaoi was broken on release, but two days later realised you just need to stand behind the creep and disengage when she uses her ult.

But you also have to take a look at the fact that not all heavily powerful/overpowered champs are popular, and it's basically because they are stale.
Take Yorick and Urgot, pick them up and you'll win.
Urgot got played in the championships last year, there were pros saying he's super strong. But his popularity didn't rise, despite the buffs he got that made him even stronger.
Yorick is incredibly strong at the moment, but no one notices him.
He has incredible sustain, damage resistance and consistent damage. Everything you want to win top lane in the past five years.
But no one is playing him.

I still dont like her chase, unlike draven, its permanent and costs nothing, but i do agree, silver bolts are hopeless, you can build health, armour or magic resist, and either way you'll die just as quickly. (no wonder tanks are doing so much damage atm, theres no other way to play them) 

I agree with Ryze, they did a great job on him. Personally i like champions being underwhelming on release, Both Aurelion Sol and Taliyah (yes... even with the changes to her w...) are 2 of my 3 favourite champs, and I'm glad that no one plays them.

Yasuo has been fucked from day 1 and everyone (except Riot apparently) knows it.

The reason Urgot and Yorick are not popular even though they are strong is because the aren't impressive to play. Contrary to popular belief, it has nothing to do with how ugly they are (Jax is just as hideous and outdated and look at his popularity) They just dont have all the flashy mechanics of Zed and Lee Sin. People want to 'feel' skilled, so they play champs like Lee and Zed that make them look skilled while they actually aren't.
Urgot and Yorick, just stand there and throw damage around you, its not that impressive to look at.

I think you're being a bit too hard on assassin players in general. Although there is a fair share of people who want to show off, I think one of the core reasons that assassins are so popular is that they can honestly feel exhilarating to play. Lots of games, nowadays love a game that is faced paced, and assassins such as Zed and Katarina promise this.

Many players are "loyal" to playing what ever they believe gives them the best chance of winning. That doesn't necessarily mean they don't appreciate the design of whatever champion it happens to be at that time. I mean, I probably won't play Kled more than a few times, being a support main, but that don't mean I think any less of him.
This always has and always will be the case with most champs.
Yes, its just a shame that most people only care about power.

I felt this should be obvious. People in ranked play to win and if a champion is weak then it won't get played as much.  Loyalty to a champion is for normal games or champions that even with damage nerfs still have strong utility. Whilst playing the same champion alot can make you alot better at that champion, if you can learn and master something else that is more powerful in the meta it will definitely help you climb.
